Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Bats, Bugs and Pecans: Using Next-Generation Pyrosequencing to Evaluate Ecosystem Services of Insectivorous Bats
Award.AbstractNarration:
Insect-eating bats are thought to provide important ecosystem services and economic benefits in agricultural systems through suppression of insect pests. Few studies, however, have attempted to describe these services and benefits, due to difficulties in identification of insect prey and lack of information on the use of agricultural landscapes by bats. This project integrates these components to describe ecological relationships between insects and bats within pecan orchards in Texas. More specifically, the research will test the hypothesis that bats contribute to the suppression of several nocturnal pests that damage pecan crops. Harnessing cutting-edge techniques, this study will use DNA from bat guano to identify with great accuracy what different species of bats are eating. The research will address fundamental ecological questions, such as the differential use of prey resources between species of bats. For example, we predict that the total number of agricultural pest species detected in bat diets will increase as more bat species are included in the analysis, reflecting variation in diet among bat species.

Demonstrating the ecosystem services provided by bats to landowners may lead to increased adoption of sustainable agriculture practices, reduced costs of pest management, and enhancement of bat habitat on private land. The results of this study will be incorporated into the Texas Integrated Pest Management (IPM) program for pecans and will be distributed to pecan growers in the form of presentations at conferences, informational pamphlets, and in Texas A&M publications (both in print and online). Over the past three years, local pecan growers have been actively engaged in this project and educational workshops about bats and agriculture have been presented in Texas and Massachusetts schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Elizabeth Braun de Torrez has completed research for her dissertation: “Bats, Insects and Pecans:? Habitat Use and Ecosystem Services of Insectivorous Bats in a Pecan Agroecosystem in Central Texas” supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. This grant provided Braun de Torrez with training in molecular dietary analysis and next-generation DNA sequencing methods. This project was specifically designed to appeal to a broader audience and for its applicability to sustainable agriculture.

Insectivorous bats have long been thought to provide important ecological and economic benefits through consumption of insect pests. Few studies, however, have been able to fully document this ecosystem service, due in part to difficulties in identification of specific prey items in the diet. Traditional methods relied on identification of chewed up insect parts in bat guano using a dissecting microscope. However, this method is extremely time-consuming, is limited to broad groups of insects (e.g., beetles, moths) rather than particular species (e.g., lady bug) and likely underrepresents soft-bodied or small insects (e.g., moths, mosquitos). In our study, we used a novel genetic technique to identify insect species in bat guano in order to understand bat-insect interactions within an agricultural landscape (pecan orchards) in central Texas. Specifically, we were able to estimate the number of insect and agricultural pest species eaten by four species of bats (Brazilian free-tailed bats, cave myotis, eastern red bats and evening bats), the amount of overlap in the diets among these species and the factors influencing diet. We were also able to generate preliminary information on the diet of a fifth species (tri-colored bat) for which we had limited samples.

We found that dietary richness (number of insect species eaten) increased with body condition of the bat, was higher in juveniles than adults, and was lower in eastern red bats than all other species. Furthermore, we found that lactating female evening bats had higher dietary richness than pregnant, post-lactating and non-reproductive females. These results suggest that eastern red bats, adults, and bats with lower body condition tend to specialize more than their counterparts, or that they forage in areas of lower insect diversity. Lactating female evening bats may eat a higher number of insect species due to longer or more wide-ranging foraging trips during this energetically demanding period when they have to nurse their pups. Several important agricultural pest species were discovered in the diets of bats, including, but not limited to: Hickory shoot borer moth, Hickory shuckworm, Pecan nut casebearer moth, Green stink bug, Corn earworm moth, Fall army worm, True army worm, and Cotton cutworm. All of these species feed on pecan trees or other food crop species within the study area. We also found several species of mosquitos to frequently occur in the diets of all bat species. For example, a common mosquito, Aedes sp., was found in the diets of 105 individuals (22.5% of total bats). Mosquitos have not traditionally been considered to be an important prey source for bats, due to their extremely small size and the high energy likely required to capture them (low bang for buck).

The use of cutting-edge genetic tools to analyze diets offers extraordinary potential to understand predator-prey interactions at a level of detail not possible with traditional techniques. Interest in these techniques for diet analysis has increased dramatically in the past 5 years. Studies of bat diets using similar techniques have recently been conducted in Canada, Europe and parts of Africa and Latin America.
